Figure 3: Accuracy of the spatial prediction process with c = 1,5,10, and 20. We note on each the 90% threshold, where 90% of predicted points fall within x absolute difference from their real value. The default is c 5, which balances accuracy and speed. =

Figure 6: The spatial analysis panel compares two runs (included predicted runs) to each other, spatially and via scatterplot views. The line chart at left shows the time series of the two runs and the left scatterplot aggregates the daily statistical views together.

Figure 9: This shows how dropping four overly influential runs helps to improve an emulator: (a, d) The run influences are more stable, (b, e) MSE decreases and R2 increases slightly, and (c, f) two outlier points (highlighted in the top plot) are removed.

Figure 7: The input parameters panel and the three built emulators for the initial use case. In (A). only runs with a Seasona[=YES value are loaded. For the built emulators (B-D), the error residu­ als and run influences charts are similar, but the difference in the parameter influences is notable. For LR (B), they have relatively smooth influences. The SS model (C) uses interaction terms, and the NP model (D) defines parameters across its three features.

Figure 8: Hovering over a set of points in the star coordinates plot highlights the runs in the corresponding bar chart and time series. We can see that the highlighted runs have different time series from the predicted run even though they match on the three input param­ eters that were used for the prediction.
